content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are somewhat careful and tend to avoid taking risks unless absolutely necessary. You weigh the pros and cons thoroughly before making decisions. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

I would choose strategy {B} as a human player. This is because, in this game, both players have an incentive to mimic each other's choices to earn more money over the long run (75 rounds).

If we always pick R, our opponent can exploit this by consistently picking B and earning 40$ on every round when we choose R. This would result in us earning 0$ on those rounds, significantly reducing our overall earnings compared to if we had chosen B instead.

Conversely, if we always pick B, our opponent can also mimic our strategy and earn 20$ on every round when we choose B, while we only get 20$. Again, this would result in us earning less money over the long run compared to if we had chosen R instead.

However, if both players stick with a mixed strategy (i.e., occasionally picking R and B) and try to mimic each other's choices as closely as possible, they can maximize their earnings by getting 40$ for every round where the opponent chooses R when we choose B, while still earning 20$ on the rounds where both players pick B.

Since our goal is to earn more money over the long run (75 rounds), it seems rational to adopt a mixed strategy that occasionally picks R and mostly picks B, in an attempt to mimic the opponent's choices as closely as possible. In this case, I would choose {B} as my initial choice.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

I would choose strategy {R} for the next round, given my goal of maximizing my earnings over the long run (75 rounds). In this particular scenario, I chose B in the previous round, but my opponent chose R, earning me a payoff of 40$. Since my opponent has already chosen R, I can exploit this by choosing R myself to earn 45$ for both of us in the next round.

After this round, we have 74 rounds left, and I would continue analyzing the situation and making choices accordingly, trying to maximize my earnings over those remaining rounds while mimicking the opponent's choices as closely as possible. In future rounds, if the opponent chooses R when I choose B, I will stick with my strategy of occasionally picking R and mostly choosing B to maintain a mixed strategy. If the opponent switches their choice and starts choosing B more often, I may also adjust my strategy accordingly to maximize my earnings.
